text:
The **economy of Uzbekistan** , formerly a Soviet-style command economy, has
undergone changes that align more with a market economy. Under the
administration of Islam Karimov, currency conversion capacity was restricted,
imports were controlled and Uzbekistan's borders with neighboring Kazakhstan,
Kyrgyzstan, and Tajikistan were sporadically closed. Since the election of
President Shavkat Mirziyoyev, Uzbekistan economic and social reforms have been
implemented to boost growth and modernize the country. International Financial
Institutions, including EBRD, Asian Development Bank and the World Bank, are
supportive of the reform process and increased their presence in the country.

Uzbekistan is a major producer and exporter of cotton. In 2022, the Cotton
Campaign and other agencies, including the US Government, lifted all bans on
the import of cotton imposed due to international human rights concerns.

Uzbekistan is also a big producer of gold, with the largest open-pit gold mine
in the world. The country has substantial deposits of silver, strategic
minerals, gas, and oil.

Since 2016, there have been significant economic reforms in Uzbekistan. The
country liberalised the currency in 2017, allowing freer flows of foreign
currency and allowing the import and export of goods, and the path to foreign
investment. 2019 tax reforms also allowed company consolidation, tax
simplification and the professionalisation of the Private sector. The
Government is also committed to privatisation of State Owned Enterprises
(SOEs), with the domestic IPO of UzAuto predicted in 2022.

The Uzbekistan Economic Forum run by the Ministry of Finance brings together
IFIs, businesses, government officials and other stakeholders on an annual
basis. The first iteration was in Tashkent, and the Uzbekistan Economic Forum
II took place in Samarkand. In December 2022, the Uzbek Government received a
loan from the World Bank of almost US$1bn to "implement strategic reforms".
Today, the volume of GDP of Uzbekistan has reached 146 billion dollars.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Uzbekistan, previously structured as a Soviet-style command economy, has transitioned toward a market economy framework.

• Under President Islam Karimov’s administration, currency conversion capacity was restricted, imports were tightly controlled, and Uzbekistan’s borders with Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and Tajikistan were intermittently closed.
• Since the election of President Shavkat Mirziyoyev, Uzbekistan has implemented economic and social reforms aimed at stimulating growth and modernizing the country.

• International Financial Institutions (IFIs) such as the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and the World Bank have supported Uzbekistan’s reform process and increased their operational presence in the country.

• Uzbekistan is a major global producer and exporter of cotton; in 2022, the Cotton Campaign and other organizations, including the US Government, lifted all bans on cotton imports that had been imposed due to international human rights concerns.
• The country is also a significant producer of gold, hosting the largest open-pit gold mine in the world, and possesses substantial deposits of silver, strategic minerals, natural gas, and oil.

• Since 2016, Uzbekistan has undertaken significant economic reforms, including the liberalization of its currency in 2017, which facilitated freer foreign currency flows and eased the import and export of goods, thereby opening pathways for foreign investment.
• Tax reforms enacted in 2019 enabled company consolidation, simplified the tax system, and promoted the professionalization of the private sector.
• The government has committed to the privatization of State Owned Enterprises (SOEs), with the domestic Initial Public Offering (IPO) of UzAuto anticipated in 2022.

• The Uzbekistan Economic Forum, organized by the Ministry of Finance, convenes annually to bring together IFIs, businesses, government officials, and other stakeholders; the first forum was held in Tashkent, followed by the second in Samarkand.
• In December 2022, the Uzbek Government secured a loan of nearly US$1 billion from the World Bank to support the implementation of strategic reforms.
• As of the latest data, Uzbekistan’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) has reached a volume of 146 billion US dollars.

This is a chart depicting the trend of the gross domestic product in
Uzbekistan in constant prices of 1995, estimated by the International Monetary
Fund with figures in millions of soum. The chart also shows the consumer price
index(CPI) as a measure of inflation from the same source and the end-of-year
U.S. dollar exchange rate from the Central Bank of the Uzbekistan database.
For purchasing power parity comparisons in 2006, the U.S. dollar is exchanged
at 340 som.

Year | GDP (constant prices) | US Dollar Exchange | CPI (2000=100)
---|---|---|---
1992 | 330,042 | 1 soum | 0.07
1995 | 302,790 | 36 soum | 20
2000 | 356,325 | 325 soum | 100
2003 | 402,361 | 980 soum | 166
2006 | 497,525 | 1,240 soum | 226
Uzbekistan: growth of GDP in constant prices 1992–2008

Uzbekistan's GDP, like that of all CIS countries, declined during the first
years of transition and then recovered after 1995, as the cumulative effect of
policy reforms began to be felt. It showed robust growth, rising by 4% per
year between 1998 and 2003, and accelerating thereafter to 7–8% per year. In
2011 the growth rate rose to 9%.

Given the growing economy, the total number of people employed rose from 8.5
million in 1995 to 13.5 million in 2011. This increase of nearly 25% in the
labor force lagged behind the increase in GDP during the same period (64%, see
chart), which implied a significant increase in labor productivity. Official
unemployment is low: less than 30,000 job seekers were registered in
government labor exchanges in 2005–2006 (0.3% of the labor force).
Underemployment, on the other hand, is quite high, especially in agriculture,
which accounts for fully 28% of all employed, many working part-time on small
household plots.

The minimum wage, public-sector wages, and old-age pensions are raised twice a
year to ensure that base income is not eroded by inflation. Although no
statistics are published on average wages in Uzbekistan, pensions as a proxy
for the average wage increased significantly between 1995 and 2006, both in
real terms and in U.S. dollars. The monthly old-age pension increased in real
(CPI-adjusted) soums by almost a factor of 5 between 1995 and 2006. The
monthly pension in U.S. dollars was around $20–$25 until 2000, then dropped to
$15–$20 between 2001 and 2004, and now is $64. The minimum wage was raised to
$34.31 in November 2011. Assuming that the average wages in the country are at
a level of 3–4 times the monthly pension, we estimate the wages in 2006 at
$100–$250 per month, or $3–$8 per day.

According to the forecast by the Asian Development Bank, the GDP in Uzbekistan
in 2009 was expected to grow by 7%. Meanwhile, in 2010 the Uzbekistan GDP
growth is predicted at 6,5%.
openai_summarised_points: • The chart presents Uzbekistan's gross domestic product (GDP) in constant 1995 prices, measured in millions of soum, as estimated by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), alongside the consumer price index (CPI) as an inflation measure from the same source, and the end-of-year U.S. dollar exchange rate from the Central Bank of Uzbekistan database.
• For purchasing power parity comparisons in 2006, the U.S. dollar was exchanged at a rate of 340 soum.
• Key data points from the chart include:
• In 1992, GDP was 330,042 million soum, the U.S. dollar exchange rate was 1 soum per dollar, and CPI was 0.07 (with 2000=100).
• In 1995, GDP was 302,790 million soum, exchange rate was 36 soum per dollar, and CPI was 20.
• In 2000, GDP rose to 356,325 million soum, exchange rate was 325 soum per dollar, and CPI was 100.
• In 2003, GDP reached 402,361 million soum, exchange rate was 980 soum per dollar, and CPI was 166.
• In 2006, GDP was 497,525 million soum, exchange rate was 1,240 soum per dollar, and CPI was 226.

• Uzbekistan’s GDP, similar to other Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) countries, experienced a decline during the early transition years post-Soviet Union, followed by recovery after 1995 due to the cumulative effects of policy reforms.
• Between 1998 and 2003, Uzbekistan’s GDP grew at an average annual rate of 4%, accelerating to 7–8% per year thereafter, with the growth rate reaching 9% in 2011.
• The total employed population increased from 8.5 million in 1995 to 13.5 million in 2011, representing nearly a 25% increase in the labor force over this period.
• Despite the labor force growth, GDP increased by 64% during the same timeframe, indicating a significant rise in labor productivity.
• Official unemployment rates are very low, with fewer than 30,000 registered job seekers in government labor exchanges during 2005–2006, equating to approximately 0.3% of the labor force.
• Underemployment remains high, particularly in the agricultural sector, which employs 28% of the workforce, many of whom work part-time on small household plots.
• The minimum wage, public-sector wages, and old-age pensions are adjusted biannually to prevent erosion of base income by inflation.
• Although average wage statistics are not published, old-age pensions serve as a proxy and showed significant increases between 1995 and 2006 in both real terms and U.S. dollar value.
• The monthly old-age pension increased nearly fivefold in real (CPI-adjusted) soums from 1995 to 2006.
• In U.S. dollar terms, the monthly pension was approximately $20–$25 until 2000, declined to $15–$20 between 2001 and 2004, and rose to $64 by 2006.
• The minimum wage was raised to $34.31 in November 2011.
• Estimations based on pension multiples suggest average monthly wages in Uzbekistan in 2006 ranged from $100 to $250, or approximately $3 to $8 per day.
• The Asian Development Bank forecasted Uzbekistan’s GDP growth at 7% for 2009.
• For 2010, Uzbekistan’s GDP growth was predicted to be 6.5% according to the same Asian Development Bank forecast.

Tashkent City Park

Literacy in Uzbekistan is almost universal, but in order to meet labor force
needs, hundreds of students are sent to the United States, Europe, and Japan
for university degrees, after which they commit to working for the government
for 5 years. About 60% of students who study abroad find employment with
foreign companies upon completing their degrees despite their commitment to
work for the government.

In addition, Uzbekistan subsidizes studies for students at Westminster
International University in Tashkent—one of the few Western-style institutions
in Uzbekistan. In 2002, the government "Istedod" Foundation (formerly as
"Umid" Foundation) paid for 98 out of 155 students studying at Westminster.
For the following academic year, Westminster admitted 360 students, with
Istedod paying for 160 students. Tuition is $5,200 per academic year.

In 2008 Management Development Institute of Singapore at Tashkent opened to
provide high quality education with international degrees. Tuition fee was
$5000 in 2012.

In 2009 Turin Polytechnik University was opened. It is the only university in
Central Asia that prepares high quality employees for industries. With the
closing or downsizing of many foreign firms, it is relatively easy to find
qualified employees, though salaries are very low by Western standards. Salary
caps, which the government implements in an apparent attempt to prevent firms
from circumventing restrictions on withdrawal of cash from banks, prevent many
foreign firms from paying their workers as much as they would like. Labor
market regulations in Uzbekistan are similar to those of the Soviet Union,
with all rights guaranteed but some rights unobserved. Unemployment is a
growing problem, and the number of people looking for jobs in Russia,
Kazakhstan, and Southeast Asia is increasing each year. Uzbekistan's Ministry
of Labor does not publish information on Uzbek citizens working abroad, but
Russia's Federal Migration Service reports 2.5 million Uzbek migrant workers
in Russia. There are also indications of up to 1 million Uzbek migrants
working illegally in Kazakhstan. Uzbekistan's migrant workers may thus be
around 3.5–4 million people, or a staggering 25% of its labor force of 14.8
million. The U.S. Department of State also estimates that between three and
five million Uzbek citizens of working age live outside Uzbekistan.

After acknowledging the need for more higher education to support labor market
needs, new programs were opened and cooperation commenced with foreign
universities. Moreover, private higher education providers started to emerge
on the market to provide students with necessary skills, knowledge and
competencies required on the labor market. One of the private universities in
Tashkent TEAM University aims at development of skills necessary for starting
entrepreneurial activities, thus contributing to development of businesses and
private enterprises.
openai_summarised_points: • Literacy in Uzbekistan is nearly universal, reflecting a high level of basic education across the population.

• To address labor force needs, hundreds of Uzbek students are sent abroad annually to the United States, Europe, and Japan for university degrees, with a government-mandated commitment to work for the Uzbek government for five years after graduation.
• Despite this commitment, approximately 60% of students who study abroad secure employment with foreign companies upon completing their degrees.
• Uzbekistan provides subsidies for students attending Westminster International University in Tashkent, one of the few Western-style institutions in the country.
• In 2002, the government’s "Istedod" Foundation (formerly "Umid" Foundation) funded 98 out of 155 students studying at Westminster International University in Tashkent.
• For the 2003 academic year, Westminster admitted 360 students, with the Istedod Foundation subsidizing tuition for 160 students.
• Tuition fees at Westminster International University in Tashkent are set at $5,200 per academic year.
• The Management Development Institute of Singapore at Tashkent was established in 2008 to provide high-quality education with internationally recognized degrees.
• Tuition fees at the Management Development Institute of Singapore at Tashkent were $5,000 in 2012.
• In 2009, Turin Polytechnic University was opened in Uzbekistan, becoming the only university in Central Asia focused on preparing high-quality employees for industrial sectors.
• Despite the availability of qualified employees due to the downsizing or closure of many foreign firms, salaries in Uzbekistan remain very low compared to Western standards.
• The Uzbek government enforces salary caps, apparently to prevent firms from circumventing restrictions on cash withdrawals from banks, which limits foreign firms’ ability to pay higher wages.
• Labor market regulations in Uzbekistan resemble those of the Soviet Union, guaranteeing all labor rights in principle, though some rights are not fully observed in practice.
• Unemployment is a growing issue in Uzbekistan, prompting an increasing number of citizens to seek employment abroad, particularly in Russia, Kazakhstan, and Southeast Asia.

• The Uzbekistan Ministry of Labor does not publish official data on Uzbek citizens working abroad; however, Russia’s Federal Migration Service reports approximately 2.5 million Uzbek migrant workers in Russia.
• There are indications of up to 1 million Uzbek migrants working illegally in Kazakhstan.
• The total number of Uzbek migrant workers abroad is estimated to be between 3.5 and 4 million people, representing about 25% of Uzbekistan’s labor force of 14.8 million.
• The U.S. Department of State estimates that between three and five million Uzbek citizens of working age live outside Uzbekistan.
• Recognizing the need for expanded higher education to support labor market demands, Uzbekistan has opened new academic programs and initiated cooperation with foreign universities.
• Private higher education providers have emerged in Uzbekistan to equip students with skills, knowledge, and competencies required by the labor market.

• TEAM University, a private university in Tashkent, focuses on developing entrepreneurial skills among students, thereby contributing to the growth of businesses and private enterprises in Uzbekistan.

text:
Uzbekistan experienced galloping inflation of around 1000% per year
immediately after independence (1992–1994). Stabilization efforts implemented
with active guidance from the International Monetary Fund rapidly paid off, as
inflation rates were brought down to 50% in 1997 and then to 22% in 2002.
Since 2003 annual inflation rates averaged less than 10%.

The severe inflationary pressures that characterized the early years of
independence inevitably led to a dramatic depreciation of the national
currency. The exchange rate of Uzbekistan's first currency, the "notional"
rouble inherited from the Soviet period and its successor, the transient
"coupon soum" introduced in November 1993 in a ratio of 1:1 to the rouble,
went up from 100 roubles/US$ in the early 1992 to 3,627 roubles (or coupon
soum) in mid-April 1994. On July 1, 1994, the "coupon soum" was replaced with
the permanent new Uzbek soum (UZS) in a ratio of 1000:1, and the starting
exchange rate for the new national currency was set at 7 soum/US$, implying an
almost two-fold depreciation since mid-April. Within the first six months,
between July and December 1994, the national currency depreciated further to
25 soum/US$ and continued depreciating at a fast clip until December 2002,
when the exchange rate had reached 969 soum/US$, i.e., 138 times the starting
exchange rate eight and a half years earlier or nearly 10,000 times the
exchange rate in early 1992, soon after the declaration of independence. Then
the depreciation of the soum virtually stopped in response to the government's
stabilization program, which at the same time dramatically reduced the
inflation rates. During the four years that followed (2003–2007) the exchange
rate of the soum to the US dollar increased only by a factor of 1.33, from 969
soum to around 1,865 soum in May 2012.

From 1996 until the spring of 2003, the official and so-called "commercial"
exchange rate – both set administratively by the Central Bank – were highly
overvalued. Many businesses and individuals were unable to buy dollars legally
at these "low" rates, so a widespread black market developed to meet hard
currency demand. The spread between the official exchange rate and the curb
rate widened especially after the 1998 Russian financial crisis: at the end of
1999 the curb rate stood at 550 soum/US$ compared with the official rate of
140 soum/US$, a gap by nearly a factor of 4 (up from a factor of "only" 2 in
1997 and the first half of 1998). By mid-2003, the government's stabilization
and liberalization efforts had reduced the gap between the black market,
official, and commercial rates to approximately 8% and it quickly disappeared
as the soum was made convertible after October 2003. Today, four foreign
currencies—the U.S. dollar, the euro, the pound sterling, and the yen—are
freely exchanged in commercial booths all around the cities, while other
currencies, including the Russian rouble and the Kazakh tenge, are bought and
sold by individual ("black market") money changers, who are allowed to operate
openly without harassment. The foreign exchange regime since October 2003 is
characterized as "controlled floating rate". Liberalization of the trade
regime remains a prerequisite for Uzbekistan to proceed to an IMF-financed
program. In 2012, "black market" rate is again significantly higher than
official rate, 2,850 soum/US$ vs. 1,865 soum/US$ (as of mid-June 2011). This
curb rate is often referred to as 'bazar rate', because money changers operate
at or near 'bazars' – large farmer markets.

Tax collection rates remained high, due to the use of the banking system by
the government as a collection agency. Technical assistance from the World
Bank, Office of Technical Assistance at the U.S. Treasury Department, and UNDP
is being provided in reforming the Central Bank and Ministry of Finance into
institutions capable of conducting market-oriented fiscal and monetary policy.
openai_summarised_points: • Following Uzbekistan's independence, the country experienced extreme inflation rates of approximately 1000% annually during the period 1992–1994.
• Stabilization measures, implemented with active guidance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), successfully reduced inflation to 50% by 1997 and further down to 22% by 2002.
• From 2003 onwards, Uzbekistan maintained annual inflation rates averaging below 10%, indicating significant macroeconomic stabilization.
• The early years of independence saw severe inflationary pressures that caused a dramatic depreciation of Uzbekistan's national currency.
• Initially, Uzbekistan used the "notional" rouble inherited from the Soviet Union, followed by the "coupon soum" introduced in November 1993 at a 1:1 ratio to the rouble.
• The exchange rate depreciated from 100 roubles per US dollar in early 1992 to 3,627 roubles (or coupon soum) by mid-April 1994.
• On July 1, 1994, the "coupon soum" was replaced by the permanent Uzbek soum (UZS) at a conversion ratio of 1000:1, with the initial exchange rate set at 7 soum per US dollar.
• This initial soum exchange rate implied nearly a two-fold depreciation compared to mid-April 1994.
• Between July and December 1994, the soum further depreciated to 25 soum per US dollar and continued to depreciate rapidly until December 2002.
• By December 2002, the exchange rate reached 969 soum per US dollar, representing a 138-fold depreciation from the starting rate in 1994 and nearly 10,000-fold since early 1992.
• After 2002, the soum’s depreciation effectively ceased due to government stabilization programs that also significantly lowered inflation.
• From 2003 to 2007, the soum depreciated only modestly by a factor of 1.33, reaching approximately 1,865 soum per US dollar by May 2012.
• Between 1996 and spring 2003, both the official and "commercial" exchange rates were administratively set by the Central Bank and were highly overvalued.
• Due to restricted access to dollars at official rates, a widespread black market for foreign currency emerged to satisfy demand.
• The gap between official and black market ("curb") exchange rates widened notably after the 1998 Russian financial crisis.
• At the end of 1999, the black market rate was 550 soum per US dollar, nearly four times higher than the official rate of 140 soum, up from a factor of two in 1997 and early 1998.
• By mid-2003, government stabilization and liberalization efforts reduced the gap between official, commercial, and black market rates to approximately 8%.
• The gap disappeared rapidly after October 2003 when the soum was made convertible, marking a shift to a "controlled floating rate" foreign exchange regime.
• Since October 2003, four foreign currencies—the U.S. dollar, euro, pound sterling, and yen—have been freely exchanged at commercial booths throughout Uzbek cities.
• Other currencies, including the Russian rouble and Kazakh tenge, are traded by individual money changers operating openly without harassment, often referred to as "black market" dealers.
• Despite liberalization, Uzbekistan’s trade regime remains partially controlled, and further liberalization is a prerequisite for participation in IMF-financed programs.
• By mid-June 2011, the "black market" or "bazar rate" for the US dollar was significantly higher than the official rate, at 2,850 soum versus 1,865 soum per US dollar.
• The term "bazar rate" derives from money changers operating near large farmer markets ("bazars") where unofficial currency exchange occurs.
• Tax collection rates in Uzbekistan remained high due to the government’s use of the banking system as a collection mechanism.

• Technical assistance for reforming Uzbekistan’s Central Bank and Ministry of Finance has been provided by the World Bank, the Office of Technical Assistance at the U.S. Treasury Department, and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).
• These reforms aim to develop institutions capable of implementing market-oriented fiscal and monetary policies in Uzbekistan.

text:
In 2018, Uzbekistan produced:

* 5.4 million tonnes of wheat;
* 2.9 million tons of potato;
* 2.2 million tons of cotton (8th largest producer in the world);
* 2.2 million tons of tomato (14th largest producer in the world);
* 2.1 million tonnes of carrot (2nd largest producer in the world, just behind China);
* 1.8 million tons of watermelon (8th largest producer in the world);
* 1.5 million tons of grape (15th largest producer in the world);
* 1.4 million tons of onion (15th largest producer in the world);
* 1.1 million tons of apple (14th largest producer in the world);
* 857 thousand tons of cucumber (7th largest producer in the world);
* 743 thousand tons of cabbage;
* 493 thousand tons of apricot (2nd largest producer in the world, just behind Turkey);
* 413 thousand tons of maize;
* 254 thousand tons of garlic;
* 221 thousand tons of rice;
* 172 thousand tons of cherry;
* 161 thousand tons of peach;
* 134 thousand tons of plum (17th largest producer in the world);

In addition to smaller productions of other agricultural products.

At the end of 2013, the government announced through the Central Bank of the
Republic of Uzbekistan that it predicted agriculture as playing a major
component of the country's economic development in the future. Agriculture in
Uzbekistan employs 28% of labor force and contributes 24% of GDP (2006 data).
Another 8% of GDP is from processing of domestic agricultural output. Cotton,
once Uzbekistan's star cash earner, has lost much its luster since
independence as wheat began to gain prominence from considerations of food
security for the rapidly growing population. Areas cropped to cotton were
reduced by more than 25% from 2 million hectares in 1990 to less than 1.5
million hectares in 2006, while wheat cultivation jumped 60% from around 1
million hectares in 1990 to 1.6 million hectares in 2006. Cotton production
dropped from 3 million tons annually in the pre-independence decade to around
1.2 million tons since 1995, but even at these reduced levels Uzbekistan
produces 3 times as much cotton as all the other Central Asian countries and
Azerbaijan combined. Cotton exports tumbled from highs of around 45% of
Uzbekistan's total exports in the early 1990s to 17% in 2006. Uzbekistan is
the largest producer of jute in West Asia and it also produces significant
quantities of silk (Uzbek ikat), fruit, and vegetables, with food products
contributing nearly 8% of total exports in 2006. Virtually all agriculture
requires irrigation, but because of budgetary constraints there has been
practically no expansion of irrigated area since independence: it remains
static at 4.2 million hectares, the level reached by 1990 after rapid growth
during the Soviet period.

Government intervention in agriculture is reflected in the persistence of
state orders for the two main cash crops, cotton and wheat. Farmers receive
binding directives on the area to be cropped to these commodities and are
obliged to surrender their harvest to designated marketers at state-fixed
prices. The incomes of farmers and agricultural workers are substantially
lower than the national average because the government pays them less than the
world prices for their cotton and wheat, using the difference to subsidize
capital intensive industrial concerns, such as factories producing
automobiles, airplanes, and tractors. Consequently, many farmers focus on
production of fruits and vegetables on their small household plots, because
the prices of these commodities are determined by supply and demand, not by
government decrees. Farmers also resort to smuggling cotton and especially
wheat across the border with Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan in order to obtain
higher prices.

The government's pricing for the main cash crops, cotton and wheat, is
apparently responsible for the exceptionally rapid growth of the cattle herd
in recent years, as the prices of milk and meat, like those of fruits and
vegetables, are also determined by market forces. The number of cattle
increased from 4 million head in 1990 to 7 million head in 2006, and virtually
all these animals are maintained by rural families with just 2–3 head per
household. Sales of own-produced milk, meat, and vegetables in town markets
are an important source for augmenting rural family incomes.

The Soviet practice of using "volunteer labor" to help gathering the cotton
harvest continues in Uzbekistan where schoolchildren, university students,
medical professionals, and state employees are driven en masse out to the
fields every year. A recent article posted by a domestic news agency
(admittedly with strong anti-government leanings) describes Uzbekistan's
cotton as "riches gathered by the hands of hungry children".
openai_summarised_points: • In 2018, Uzbekistan produced 5.4 million tonnes of wheat, establishing it as a significant crop in the country’s agricultural output.
• Potato production in Uzbekistan reached 2.9 million tons in 2018, highlighting its importance in the national diet and agriculture.
• Uzbekistan was the 8th largest cotton producer globally in 2018, producing 2.2 million tons of cotton.
• Tomato production stood at 2.2 million tons in 2018, ranking Uzbekistan as the 14th largest producer worldwide.
• The country produced 2.1 million tonnes of carrots in 2018, making it the 2nd largest carrot producer in the world, second only to China.
• Watermelon production was 1.8 million tons in 2018, with Uzbekistan ranking as the 8th largest producer globally.
• Grape production reached 1.5 million tons in 2018, placing Uzbekistan as the 15th largest producer in the world.
• Onion production was 1.4 million tons in 2018, also ranking Uzbekistan 15th globally.
• Apple production totaled 1.1 million tons in 2018, with Uzbekistan ranked 14th in the world.
• Cucumber production was 857 thousand tons in 2018, making Uzbekistan the 7th largest producer worldwide.
• Cabbage production amounted to 743 thousand tons in 2018, indicating its role in local agriculture.
• Apricot production was 493 thousand tons in 2018, ranking Uzbekistan as the 2nd largest apricot producer globally, just behind Turkey.
• Maize production reached 413 thousand tons in 2018, contributing to the country’s cereal output.
• Garlic production was 254 thousand tons in 2018, reflecting its agricultural significance.
• Rice production totaled 221 thousand tons in 2018, supporting dietary and economic needs.
• Cherry production was 172 thousand tons in 2018, contributing to fruit agriculture.
• Peach production reached 161 thousand tons in 2018, indicating its cultivation scale.
• Plum production was 134 thousand tons in 2018, with Uzbekistan ranked 17th largest producer globally.
• Besides these major crops, Uzbekistan produced smaller quantities of various other agricultural products in 2018.
• At the end of 2013, the Uzbek government, via the Central Bank of the Republic of Uzbekistan, forecasted agriculture as a major component of future economic development.
• Agriculture employed 28% of Uzbekistan’s labor force and contributed 24% to GDP based on 2006 data.
• Processing of domestic agricultural output contributed an additional 8% to Uzbekistan’s GDP as of 2006.
• Cotton, once the primary cash crop and export earner, declined in prominence post-independence due to increased emphasis on wheat for food security amid population growth.
• Cotton-cropped area decreased by over 25%, from 2 million hectares in 1990 to less than 1.5 million hectares in 2006.
• Wheat cultivation increased by 60%, from about 1 million hectares in 1990 to 1.6 million hectares in 2006.
• Cotton production dropped from 3 million tons annually in the pre-independence decade to approximately 1.2 million tons since 1995.
• Despite reduced production, Uzbekistan produced three times more cotton than all other Central Asian countries combined, including Azerbaijan.
• Cotton exports declined from about 45% of total exports in the early 1990s to 17% in 2006.
• Uzbekistan is the largest producer of jute in West Asia and also produces significant quantities of silk (notably Uzbek ikat), fruit, and vegetables.
• Food products contributed nearly 8% of Uzbekistan’s total exports in 2006.

• Nearly all agricultural production in Uzbekistan requires irrigation; however, due to budget constraints, the irrigated area has remained static at 4.2 million hectares since 1990, following rapid Soviet-era expansion.

• Government intervention persists through state orders for cotton and wheat, with farmers receiving binding directives on crop areas and required to sell harvests at state-fixed prices to designated marketers.

• Farmers’ incomes are substantially lower than the national average because the government pays below world prices for cotton and wheat, using the price differential to subsidize capital-intensive industries such as automobile, airplane, and tractor manufacturing.
• Due to fixed low prices for cotton and wheat, many farmers focus on fruit and vegetable production on small household plots, where prices are market-determined rather than state-controlled.
• Some farmers engage in smuggling cotton and especially wheat across borders with Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan to obtain higher prices.
• The government’s pricing policy for cotton and wheat has contributed to rapid growth in the cattle herd, as prices for milk and meat are market-determined.
• The cattle population increased from 4 million head in 1990 to 7 million head in 2006, with most animals maintained by rural families owning 2–3 head each.
• Sales of self-produced milk, meat, and vegetables in urban markets provide important supplementary income for rural families.

• The Soviet-era practice of mobilizing "volunteer labor" for cotton harvest continues in Uzbekistan, involving schoolchildren, university students, medical professionals, and state employees who are sent en masse to the fields annually.

Since the 2017 liberalisation of the foreign exchange market, Uzbekistan has
seen rapid growth in exports. Traditional export products such as gas and
cotton are now kept domestically for processing. They have been replaced by a
vast growth in exports in areas such as fruit, textiles and home appliances.
In recent years textile export has doubled in revenue to almost US$3bn worth
of goods exports. Home appliance manufacturer Artel has seen exports rise from
$5.6m in 2017, to around $100m in 2021.

Before this, the system of multiple exchange rates combined with the highly
regulated trade regime caused both imports and exports to drop each from about
US$4.5 billion in 1996 to less than US$3 billion in 2002. The success of
stabilization and currency liberalization in 2003 has led to significant
increases in exports and imports in recent years, although imports have
increased much less rapidly: while exports had more than doubled to US$15.5 by
2011, imports had risen to US$6.5 billion only, reflecting the impact of the
government's import substitution policies designed to maintain hard currency
reserves. Draconian tariffs, sporadic border closures, and border crossing
"fees" have a negative effect on legal imports of both consumer products and
capital equipment.

Uzbekistan is a member of the International Monetary Fund, World Bank, Asian
Development Bank, and European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. It has
observer status at the World Trade Organization, is a member of the World
Intellectual Property Organization, and is a signatory to the _Convention on
Settlement of Investment Disputes Between States and Nationals of Other
States_ , the _Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property_ ,
the _Madrid Agreement on Trademarks Protection_, and the _Patent Cooperation
Treaty_. In 2002, Uzbekistan was again placed on the special "301" Watch List
for lack of intellectual copyright protection.

Daewoo Gentra is currently a flagship of UzDaewooAuto.

Until 2017, according to EBRD transition indicators, Uzbekistan's investment
climate remains among the least favorable in the CIS, with only Belarus and
Turkmenistan ranking lower. The unfavorable investment climate has caused
foreign investment inflows to dwindle to a trickle. It is believed that
Uzbekistan has the lowest level of foreign direct investment per capita in the
CIS. Since Uzbekistan's independence, U.S. firms have invested roughly $500
million in the country, but due to declining investor confidence, harassment,
and currency convertibility problems, numerous international investors have
left the country or are considering leaving. In 2005, the Central Bank has
revoked the license of the nascent Biznes Bank citing unspecified violations
of local currency exchange rules. The revocation prompted immediate bankruptcy
procedures, under which clients' deposits stay arrested for two month. No
interest was accrued during that two-month period. In 2006, the Government of
Uzbekistan forced out Newmont Mining Corporation (at the time the largest U.S.
investor) from its gold mining joint venture in the Muruntau gold mine.
Newmont and the government resolved their dispute, but the action adversely
affected Uzbekistan's image among foreign investors. The government attempted
the same with British-owned Oxus Mining. Coscom, a U.S.-owned
telecommunications company, involuntarily sold its stake in a joint venture to
another foreign company. GM-DAT, a Korean subsidiary of GM, is the only known
U.S. business to have entered Uzbekistan in over two years. It recently signed
a joint-venture agreement with UzDaewooAuto to assemble Korean-manufactured
cars for export and domestic sale. Other large U.S. investors in Uzbekistan
include Case IH, manufacturing and servicing cotton harvesters and tractors;
Coca-Cola, with bottling plants in Tashkent, Namangan, and Samarkand; Texaco,
producing lubricants for sale in the Uzbek market; and Baker Hughes, in oil
and gas development.

In 2024, Uzbekistan’s external debt reached $64.1 billion, or 55.7% of GDP, up
from 51.9% in 2023. This included both public and private liabilities, though
much of the private sector; particularly banks and industrial enterprises;
remained state-owned. Government debt rose to $33.9 billion (29.5% of GDP),
while corporate external debt reached $30.2 billion (26.2%). The government
continued to control about 65% of the banking sector and held stakes in major
firms like UzAuto Motors and Uzbekneftegaz. Public debt was projected to rise
to $45.1 billion (36.7% of GDP) by the end of 2025.

In 2025, President Shavkat Mirziyoyev signed a law on Uzbekistan's accession
to the Agreement Establishing the Eurasian Development Bank (EADB). Uzbekistan
will become the seventh member of the Bank and the third largest shareholder
with a 10% equity stake.
openai_summarised_points: • Since the 2017 liberalisation of Uzbekistan's foreign exchange market, the country has experienced rapid export growth, with traditional export products such as gas and cotton now retained domestically for processing, replaced by significant increases in exports of fruit, textiles, and home appliances.

• Following stabilization and currency liberalization in 2003, Uzbekistan saw significant increases in exports and imports; by 2011, exports had more than doubled to US$15.5 billion, whereas imports rose more modestly to US$6.5 billion, reflecting government import substitution policies aimed at preserving hard currency reserves.
• The Uzbek government's use of draconian tariffs, sporadic border closures, and border crossing fees negatively impacts legal imports of consumer products and capital equipment.

• In 2002, Uzbekistan was placed on the special "301" Watch List due to inadequate intellectual copyright protection.
• Daewoo Gentra is identified as a flagship model of UzDaewooAuto, a prominent automotive company in Uzbekistan.

• Other major U.S. investors in Uzbekistan include Case IH (manufacturing and servicing cotton harvesters and tractors), Coca-Cola (operating bottling plants in Tashkent, Namangan, and Samarkand), Texaco (producing lubricants for the Uzbek market), and Baker Hughes (engaged in oil and gas development).

Uzbekistan's banks have demonstrated reasonably stable performance in a
largely state-dominated local economy. Sector stability is currently supported
by rapid economic growth, low exposure to external financial markets and the
strong external and fiscal position of the sovereign. However, the sector
remains vulnerable to possible economic shocks due to weak corporate
governance and risk management, fast recent asset growth, significant directed
lending and acquisitions of problem assets. Banks’ foreign currency
obligations, specifically those arising from trade finance, are particularly
vulnerable due to existing foreign exchange constraints.

According to Fitch Ratings, there are notable risks of asset quality
deterioration in case of a reversal in economic trends. The funding base is
mainly short-term, largely sourced from corporate current accounts, while
retail funds account for only a small 25% of total deposits. Longer-term
funding is provided by the Ministry of Finance and other state agencies, which
comprise a notable proportion of sector liabilities. Foreign funding is small,
estimated at 10% of the total liabilities, and plans for further borrowings
are moderate. Liquidity management is constrained be the lack of deep capital
markets, and banks generally tend to hold substantial cash reserves on their
balance sheets. The quality of capital is sometimes compromised by less
conservative regulatory requirements for recognition of credit impairment and
by investments in non-core assets.
openai_summarised_points: • Uzbekistan's banking sector has shown reasonably stable performance within a predominantly state-dominated local economy, supported by rapid economic growth and a strong external and fiscal sovereign position.
• The banking sector's stability benefits from low exposure to external financial markets, reducing vulnerability to global financial shocks.

• Despite stability, the sector remains susceptible to economic shocks due to weak corporate governance, inadequate risk management practices, rapid recent asset growth, significant directed lending, and acquisitions of problem assets.
• Banks’ foreign currency obligations, particularly those related to trade finance, are especially vulnerable because of existing foreign exchange constraints in Uzbekistan.
• Fitch Ratings highlights notable risks of asset quality deterioration if there is a reversal in current positive economic trends.
• The banking sector’s funding base is predominantly short-term, mainly sourced from corporate current accounts, with retail deposits constituting only 25% of total deposits.
• Longer-term funding is primarily provided by the Ministry of Finance and other state agencies, which represent a significant portion of the sector’s liabilities.
• Foreign funding accounts for a relatively small share of total liabilities, estimated at 10%, and plans for additional foreign borrowings are moderate.
• Liquidity management within banks is limited by the absence of deep capital markets, leading banks to maintain substantial cash reserves on their balance sheets as a precaution.
• The quality of bank capital is occasionally compromised due to less conservative regulatory standards for recognizing credit impairment and due to investments in non-core assets.

Uzbekistan's retail sector remains dominated by traditional markets, known as
_bozorlar_ , where individual vendors sell food, housewares, clothing, and
other consumer goods. But the country's retail sector is rapidly modernizing.
The construction of modern supermarkets and malls has accelerated in recent
years. The country's retail market was estimated at $17 billion in 2017 and
rising incomes, population growth, and a move from informal to formal retail
are expected to drive continued expansion of the sector. Major supermarket
chains include local players Korzinka.uz and Makro (Uzbekistan) and the French
multinational chain Carrefour, which will open its first store in Uzbekistan
in 2021. The country's first modern shopping malls are located in Tashkent,
and include the Samarkand Darvoza and Compass developments. The sector has
also seen growth in online retail. In 2021, Korzinka acquired a US$40m stake
in Anglesey Food, the Singapore mother entity of Korzinka. In 2021, the
company also signed a signed $12 million in debt financing to promote food
security and sustain the livelihoods of more than 5,000 employees and 1,200
farm workers in Uzbekistan.
openai_summarised_points: • Uzbekistan's retail sector is predominantly characterized by traditional markets called _bozorlar_, where individual vendors sell a variety of consumer goods including food, housewares, and clothing.

• Despite the dominance of traditional markets, the retail sector in Uzbekistan is undergoing rapid modernization, marked by the accelerated construction of modern supermarkets and shopping malls in recent years.

• In 2017, Uzbekistan's retail market was estimated to be worth $17 billion, with projections indicating continued growth driven by rising incomes, population growth, and a transition from informal to formal retail channels.

• Major supermarket chains operating in Uzbekistan include local companies Korzinka.uz and Makro (Uzbekistan), as well as the French multinational Carrefour, which planned to open its first store in Uzbekistan in 2021.
• The first modern shopping malls in Uzbekistan are located in the capital city, Tashkent, with notable developments including the Samarkand Darvoza and Compass shopping centers.
• The retail sector has also experienced significant growth in online retail platforms, reflecting broader modernization trends within the industry.
• In 2021, Korzinka expanded its business by acquiring a US$40 million stake in Anglesey Food, the Singapore-based parent company of Korzinka.
• Additionally, in 2021, Korzinka secured $12 million in debt financing aimed at promoting food security and sustaining the livelihoods of over 5,000 employees and 1,200 farm workers in Uzbekistan.

According to the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP),
Vlast, and iStories, after February 24, 2022, Uzbekistan significantly
increased its exports of cotton pulp and nitrocellulose, key components for
making explosives and gunpowder, to Russia. According to Ekonomichna Pravda,
at least two large Uzbek exporters have been working with Russian military-
industrial complex enterprises. Documents from the Russian Federal Tax Service
confirm that at least three Russian companies – Bina Group, Khimtrade, and
Lenakhim - sold imported cotton pulp to military plants in Russia. Among them:
Kazan Powder Plant (a strategic defense-industrial enterprise that produces
gunpowder and charges for various types of weapons, subject to US sanctions),
Tambov Powder Plant (a defense-industrial enterprise that produces ammunition
and special chemicals, It is subject to US and Ukrainian sanctions), Perm
Powder Plant (an enterprise involved in the production of Topol-M and Bulava
intercontinental ballistic missiles, as well as Kornet ATGMs and Grad and
Smerch multiple rocket launchers. It is under Ukrainian sanctions).
openai_summarised_points: • According to investigations by the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP), Vlast, and iStories, Uzbekistan significantly increased its exports of cotton pulp and nitrocellulose to Russia after February 24, 2022; these substances are key components used in the manufacture of explosives and gunpowder.

• Ekonomichna Pravda reported that at least two major Uzbek exporters have been collaborating with enterprises within the Russian military-industrial complex, facilitating the supply chain for military production.

• Documents obtained from the Russian Federal Tax Service confirm that at least three Russian companies—Bina Group, Khimtrade, and Lenakhim—have sold imported Uzbek cotton pulp to Russian military plants.

• The Kazan Powder Plant, one of the recipients of the cotton pulp, is a strategic defense-industrial enterprise producing gunpowder and charges for various weapon types; this plant is subject to sanctions imposed by the United States.
• The Tambov Powder Plant, another recipient, is a defense-industrial enterprise manufacturing ammunition and special chemicals; it is subject to sanctions from both the United States and Ukraine.

• The Perm Powder Plant, also supplied with cotton pulp, is involved in producing advanced weaponry including Topol-M and Bulava intercontinental ballistic missiles, Kornet anti-tank guided missiles (ATGMs), and Grad and Smerch multiple rocket launchers; this plant is under Ukrainian sanctions.

• The main economic indicators for Uzbekistan from 1993 to 2025 include GDP in billion US$ PPP and nominal terms, GDP per capita in US$ PPP and nominal, real GDP growth rates, inflation percentages, and government debt as a percentage of GDP, with detailed yearly data showing trends such as GDP growth from 46.6 billion US$ PPP in 1993 to a projected 471.9 billion US$ PPP in 2025.
• GDP per capita in PPP terms increased from 2,133 US$ in 1993 to a projected 12,596 US$ in 2025, while nominal GDP per capita rose from 316 US$ in 1993 to an estimated 3,355 US$ in 2025.

• Real GDP growth fluctuated over the years, with negative growth in the early 1990s (−2.3% in 1993 and −5.2% in 1994), followed by steady positive growth reaching peaks such as 9.5% in 2007, and projected moderate growth of 6.3% in 2025.

• Inflation rates were extremely high in the early 1990s, peaking at 1,568.3% in 1994, then declined significantly to single digits by the mid-2000s, stabilizing around 10% in recent years, with 10.0% inflation projected for 2024 and 9.4% for 2025.

• Government debt as a percentage of GDP was not available for the early 1990s but recorded at 15.3% in 1997, fluctuated thereafter, reaching a low of 6.1% in 2014, and rising again to an estimated 35.4% in 2025.

• Household income distribution in 2003 showed the lowest 10% of the population held 2.8% of income or consumption, while the highest 10% accounted for 29.6%, with a Gini index of 36.8 indicating moderate income inequality.
• Uzbekistan’s agricultural sector produces cotton, vegetables, fruits, grains, and livestock, reflecting its role in the economy.
• Industrial production growth was estimated at 6.2% in 2003, indicating moderate industrial expansion.
• Electricity production in 2002 was 47.7 TWh, with consumption at 46.66 TWh; exports were 4.5 TWh and imports 6.8 TWh, showing a near balance in electricity trade.
• Electricity production sources in 2001 were predominantly fossil fuels at 88.2%, hydroelectric power at 11.8%, with no contribution from nuclear or other sources.

• Oil production in 2004 was estimated at 143,300 barrels per day (22,780 m3/d), with consumption slightly lower at 142,000 barrels per day (22,600 m3/d) in 2001; proved oil reserves stood at 297 million barrels (47.2 million m3) as of January 1, 2002.

• Natural gas production in 2001 was 63.1 billion m3, with consumption at 45.2 billion m3; exports totaled 17.9 billion m3, imports were zero, and proved reserves were 937.3 billion m3 as of January 1, 2002.
• The current account balance was positive at $3.045 billion in 2007, indicating a surplus.

• In 2006, Uzbekistan’s export commodities included cotton (17.2%), energy products (13.1%), metals (12.9%), machinery and equipment (10.1%), food products (7.9%), chemical products (5.6%), and services (12.1%).
• Imports in 2006 were dominated by machinery and equipment (40.3%), chemical products (15.0%), metals (10.4%), food products (8.1%), energy products (4.3%), and services (9.1%).
• Foreign exchange and gold reserves were estimated at $5.6 billion as of December 2007.

• Exchange rates varied significantly over time: 1,865 Uzbekistani som (UZS) per US dollar in early 2012, depreciating to 10,097 UZS per USD by April 2020; similarly, the exchange rate for the euro was 2,900 UZS per EUR and later 10,981 UZS per EUR in April 2020.

• Economic growth in the first six months of 2009 showed a GDP increase of 8.2%, industrial production growth of 9.1%, and agricultural production growth of 4.6%, indicating robust recovery despite global economic challenges.
